node.title: Man Pardoned After Spending 24 Years in Prison for Murder
node.alt: Montoyae Dontae Sharpe in 2019 after a judge ruled he could be set free. The North Carolina governor on Friday granted Mr. Sharpe a pardon.
node.description: The pardon came after a North Carolina judge vacated the conviction of Montoyae Dontae Sharpe in 2019, ruling that a key witness had “entirely made up” her testimony.
node.content: ["Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina on Friday granted a pardon to a man who spent more than 24 years in prison for murder before a judge vacated his conviction in 2019, finding that a key witness had \u201centirely made up\u201d her testimony.", "The pardon for the man, Montoyae Dontae Sharpe, clears the way for him to seek compensation from the state and comes after prominent pastors and others had demonstrated outside the governor\u2019s mansion in support of Mr. Sharpe.", "\u201cIt\u2019s been a long time coming,\u201d Mr. Sharpe, 46, of Charlotte, said in an interview on Friday. \u201cMy name has been cleared, and me and my family can move on. And I can go on with the next stage of my life, which is to still help other guys behind me.\u201d", "In 1995, Mr. Sharpe was convicted and sentenced to life in prison for the murder of George Radcliffe, who was found fatally shot in his pickup truck in Greenville, N.C., on Feb. 11, 1994.", "During the trial, Charlene Johnson, who was 15, testified that she saw Mr. Sharpe, who is Black, shoot Mr. Radcliffe, who was white, in a face-to-face altercation over a drug deal, according to one of Mr. Sharpe\u2019s lawyers, Theresa A. Newman, who was a co-director of the Wrongful Convictions Clinic at Duke University School of Law.", "Ms. Johnson testified that Mr. Sharpe and another man then put Mr. Radcliffe into the truck, crashed it into a vacant lot and threw away the key, Ms. Newman said.", "Ms. Johnson recanted her testimony weeks later, and Mr. Sharpe\u2019s efforts to overturn his conviction worked their way through the courts until 2019, when a Superior Court judge in Pitt County, N.C., held two evidentiary hearings that destroyed the case.", "After the second hearing, on Aug. 22, 2019, the judge, G. Bryan Collins Jr., found that if the case were tried again, Ms. Johnson would testify that \u201cshe was not present at the time of the shooting and that her trial testimony was entirely made up based on what she saw on television and what investigators told her.\u201d", "Judge Collins also found that the medical examiner who had testified at the trial, Dr. Mary Gilliland, learned of Ms. Johnson\u2019s testimony only \u201cwell after the trial was over.\u201d If Dr. Gilliland were called to testify at a retrial, the judge found, she would testify that Ms. Johnson\u2019s initial description of the shooting was \u201cmedically and scientifically impossible.\u201d", "Mr. Radcliffe had been shot in the arm, and Ms. Johnson\u2019s description of a face-to-face confrontation \u201cdidn\u2019t line up with the trajectory of the bullet through the body,\u201d Ms. Newman said.", "Judge Collins vacated Mr. Sharpe\u2019s conviction, released him from prison and granted his motion for a new trial.", "That same day, the Pitt County District Attorney\u2019s Office dismissed the murder charge against Mr. Sharpe and refused to retry the case on the grounds that there was insufficient evidence to prove it beyond a reasonable doubt.", "Mr. Sharpe then spent the next two years fighting for a pardon, Ms. Newman said, before Mr. Cooper granted it on Friday.", "\u201cI have carefully reviewed Montoyae Dontae Sharpe\u2019s case and am granting him a Pardon of Innocence,\u201d Mr. Cooper, a Democrat, said in a statement. \u201cMr. Sharpe and others who have been wrongly convicted deserve to have that injustice fully and publicly acknowledged.\u201d", "Ms. Newman said the pardon would allow Mr. Sharpe to petition the state for compensation of $50,000 for each year of wrongful imprisonment up to $750,000 \u2014 the most Mr. Sharpe could receive for the 24 years he spent in prison.", "Mr. Sharpe said he had been sustained throughout the decades by his faith in God, his lawyers, the pastors who supported him and his mother, who gave him the strength to resist pressure from prosecutors to accept plea deals that could have resulted in his release from prison.", "\u201cIf it weren\u2019t for them, it would have been bad,\u201d Mr. Sharpe said. \u201cI would have still been in there, most likely.\u201d", "At a rally outside the governor\u2019s mansion on Friday, the Rev. Dr. William J. Barber II, a North Carolina pastor, celebrated the \u201ctremendous, tremendous news\u201d of Mr. Sharpe\u2019s pardon and asked those in attendance to think of all those who fought for Mr. Sharpe throughout the years.", "\u201cThis was a family victory,\u201d Dr. Barber said, adding that Mr. Sharpe deserved special praise.", "\u201cHe has more courage than any man that has ever sat in that governor\u2019s office \u2014 or woman \u2014 and more courage than anybody that\u2019s ever sat in the state Legislature,\u201d Dr. Barber said.", "Mr. Sharpe said he hoped to use his pardon to fight for others who have been wrongfully convicted and are seeking to clear their names.", "\u201cI know there are more cases out there like mine because the system isn\u2019t perfect,\u201d he said. \u201cWe can change the system and my case is just a steppingstone for me to step out and help change the system.\u201d"]
